VOL. XVI, NO. 8.

MR. BOBBITT OBJECTS
Founder of the Arbitration Society Protests Against the Proposed Change
Into a Literary Organization.

Further discussion of the project
to change the Arbitration Society
into a literary organization is contained in the two letters which follow. The first, from Mr. L. B.
Bobbitt (A. B., 'ii), the organizer
of the Arbitration Society, endorses
THE NEWS-LETTER'S editorial of
November 13. The second, from
Mr. J. S. Dickinson, the president
of the Literary Society, attempts to
criticize the attitude of THE NEWS-

LETTER.
November 20, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER :
Dear Sir—Your issue of November 13 informs me that the Johns
Hopkins Arbitration Society has
resolved to transform itself into
a literary and debating society, and
.that a committee has been appointed to draft a new constitution. As
the organizer and president of the
Arbitration Society last yea,r, I regret exceedingly that this action
has been taken. In spite of the
proposal to devote at least two
meetings a year to the discussion
of matters pertaining to arbitration,
this new plan means that the distinctive . character of the Arbitration Society will be lost and that
the specific purpose for which it
was organized will be frustrated.
I believed last year, and the sentiment of a number of the students
confirmed my belief, that there was
a real place in the University for
a student society that should devote itself primarily to the study
of the judicial settlement of international disputes, and secondarily,
to the study of the peace movement
and international politics in general.
So far as I know, the Arbitration
Society that some of us formed
was the first college society of its /
kind in the country. For several//
Years a number of college literary
societies had, perhaps once or twice
a year, presented a program dealing with peace and arbitration; but
our society was, I think, the first
college society to devote itself to
these subjects exclusively. The
Work that we did, though not very
elaborate, was of some real value.
We held bi-weekly meetings, at
Which a number of excellent papers
Were presented by the members;
we were addressed by two prominent men, connected with the peace
movement, Hon. James Brown
Scott and Mr. Edwin D. Mead;
We arranged the details of the
aryland Oratorical Contest of the
Intercollegiate. Peace Association,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 27, 1911.

LECTURES BY DR. E. B. HUEY

DR. FINNEY DECLINES CALL

Course Dealing With Defective Children
Will Begin Early in January,
on Saturday Mornings.

Hopkins Professor Issues Statement Declining to be Considered for
President of Princeton.

Beginning early in January, at a
date to be announced shortly in the
public press, Dr. Edmund B. Huey,
who has recently been appointed
Lecturer on Mental Development
in the University and Assistant in
the Phipps Clinic of the Hospital,
will give a series of public lectures
on each Saturday that the University is in session, continuing to the
close of the university year.
The object of the course is, first,
to present some representative work
that is being done in the study and
treatment of defective children; second, to make as intelligible as possible, certain psychological conceptions which are currently used in
the study of cases.
After a very brief sketch of the
varied work with cases in many
parts of the world, and of the revision of psychology that is inevitably to come from this work, there
will be a presentation of the recently-adopted schema of • classification
and terminology for the various
grades of defectives. The operation of this schema will then be
illustrated by actual results obtained in handling cases at a large
State institution. The methods of
examining cases and of securing
the data needed for a proper casehistory will be illustrated. It is expected that there will be at least
two clinics in which mental examinations of children will be made
with the Binet scale. Various types
of mentally backward children as
found in school will be presented.
There will, of course, be opportunity for questions, and for such discussion as time may permit.
Besides these more practical presentations, the course will include
lectures on the intelligence, the
emotions and feelings in their relation to mental adaptation, the
tendencies to automatism, fixation
and limitation of mental response,
and the characteristics of infantilism and of various abnormal returns to "childish things" by individuals and by society. Certain
changes in these topics may be expedient as the course proceeds.
There can be relatively more of a
discussion of psychological theory
if the audience should prefer.
The lectures will begin at
o'cl6ck and will last one hour.
They will be open to the public as
well as to the members of the University. It is hoped' that they may
render a service to many who have
to do with defectives, as well as to
many ethers who have.an interest
in psychology.

Dr. John M. T. Finney, associate
professor of surgery in the Johns
Hopkins University issued a statement Friday afternoon in which he
said that he thought that Baltimore
offered more opportunities for the
work which he is fitted to do, than
would the presidency of Princeton
University. Hs formal statement
follows:
"Owing to the wide publicity
which, unfortunately, has been given
to the connection of my name with
the presidency of Princeton University, it is, perhaps, proper that
I should state the facts in the case
,in order that they may not be misunderstood. Sometime ago I was
approached by members of the
nominating committee of the Board
of Trustees of Princeton and asked
whether or not I would be willing
to have them present my name to
the Board for election to the presidency of the University.
"After most careful consideration,
from every point of view, I felt that
my work in Baltimore was not yet
done and, therefore, requested that
my name should be withdrawn.
While the call from Princeton,
which I consider one of the highest
honors that can fall to any man's
lot, came with peculiar force, it
seemed best that I should remain in
Baltimore. I felt that I was better
fitted for the work which T am now
doing."
Sophomore-Freshman Game.
The annual game of football between the sophomores and the freshmen will be played this coming Saturday, 3 P. M., at Homewood. The
sophomore class is one of three
classes which has won the game in
its first year at the University. It
defeated the Class of 1913 last fall,
18 to o, but it has lost "by graduation" five of its first string men,
the Riley brothers, Hill, Schreiber,
and Bryan. The loss depletes the
strength of the team nearly onehalf, but new men have been
brought out who will fill the vacancies and try to win again.
A second victory will give 194
a unique place in class history at
Hopkins, because no other class
team has won both games.
Both teams will practice regularly
this week.

CARLISLE WINS
The Conquerors of Harvard and Pcnn
Defeat Hopkins in a Spectacular Game

Hopkins lost last Saturday by the
score of 29 to 6, to the strongest
football team that has represented
Carlisle in recent years. The Indians
came to Baltimore with the record
of more points scored than any
other of the big teams of the East.
They have lost but one game this
year, and that to Syracuse, on a
muddy field; Saturday, however, the
sloppy condition of the field did not
seem to interfere with the Indians'
game, for they relied mostly on
quick end 'plays. Sousa, who played
such a fine game against Syracuse,
was a particularly bright star in
getting around the ends.
The first ten minutes of the game
consisted mainly in the exchange
of punts. The Hopkins line was
holding particularly well, and after
a few ineffectual attempts to gain,
the Indians would kick. The exchanges made but little difference
in the relative positions of the team,
so the Indians began to change
their tactics. It has been noticeable
the whole year, how slow the 'Varsity is in getting into place. The
Indians now took advantage of this
weakness, and by a quick dash
around Hopkins' left end, placed
the ball near the side lines on the
Hopkins half of the field. Before
Hopkins was settled again, the
Indians apparently attempted a mass
play through their left tackle. Meanwhile the man with the ball rushed
unhindered along the side line.
Score, 5 to o.
Shortly after the beginning of
the second -quarter, Gillet made a
kick from Hopkins' 25-yard line.
It was short, and Branham seized
the ball and got clear, but was
caught in mid-field by a swift
Indian runner. Carlisle soon got possession of the ball and by two long
end runs, supported by magnificent
441terference, and two line plunges,
put the ball over. Score, ii to 0.
The third touchdown was made
when Gillet was blocked in an attempt to kick from Hopkins' 25yard line and an Indian recovered
the ball. Score, 17 to o.
The Indians, receiving possession
of the ball, tried a forward pass,
which Pieper blocked. After getting the pigskin again on a punt,
the Indians made a 30-yard run
to Hopkins' 25-yard line. Here,
Quarterback Welch received a pass
and stood still for a moment as
if bewildered, then slowly drew the
ball back as if to make a forward

The St. John's Aftermath.

The aftermath of the football
games with Virginia and St. John's
has involved more controversy, in
newspapers and otherwise, than we
like to see. One fundamental principle of true sport is to accept the
outcome without protest. Such has
usually been the practice of our
neighbors from Annapolis, and we
honor them for it. On this occasion, too, the St. John's authorities
and students have shown themselves
willing to submit to a defeat at the
hands of a better team with good
feeling, just exactly as Hopkins has
done time after time when conditions were reversed; but a number
of over-zealous alumni and partisans of our rival institution have
filled the newspapers with howls
about the condition of the Homewood field, the personnel of the
Hopkins team, and various other
unworthily imagined grievances. To
these persons, we do not consider
it our place ,to reply. The facts
and conditions in question, which
have been brought out in several
able letters from prominent Hopkins graduates, are an adequate reflection of their somewhat ill-mannered attacks.
One public assault, however, was
too flagrant, and delivered in too
unfair a manner to be passed over.
THE NEWS-LETTER must object to
the treatment accorded the Hopkins
football team, and athletic authorities, in the account of the HopkinsSt. John's game which appeared in
The Sun. We leave the article itself to serve as a bill of particulars
to substantiate our complaint, and
are willing to accept the unprejudiced judgment of the spectators of
the game as to the unfairness and
inaccuracy of the statement it contains.
We cannot omit reference, also,
to the weights of the Hopkins plays, that have been published in the
local papers. We regret, exceed-

ingly, and we believe the students
unanimously join in regretting, that
the figures given out before the

The News-Letter Board.

THE NOVS-LETTER Board, owing to resignations, is now smaller
than it has been for sometime past,
and additions are contemplated. It
is certain that no freshmen, and
doubtful whether any upper classmen, will be elected until after the
Christmas holidays, and so there
is plenty of time for new candidates to announce themselves. Those
desiring to become editors should
speak to the Editor-in-Chief, while
the candidates for the business
department should speak to the
Business Manager.
Membership on THE NMS-LETTER Board is the greatest non-athletic honor which can be gained at
Hopkins, and some even subordinate athletics. A stated amount of
preliminary literary and business
work must be done by candidates
who want to be successful. Much
of this is assigned, but original
work is always welcomed. This
call for candidates is not made because there is a dearth of aspirants,
but because THE NEws-LETTER
wishes to have the best possible
Board.
Many who could easily "make
THE + F,WS-LETTER," refuse to be
candidates because they do not
think that they can spare the time
required. These students are generally the more serious minded,
who want to get all the good they
can while at Hopkins. The following excerpt from a letter written by the late Herbert B. Adams,
Professor of History, 1878-01, may
be of interest to them:
"My editorial connection with the
Amherst Student really gave a permanent bent to my life. I learned
more real useful knowledge in that
voluntary connection than in all
other college weave of training in
punctuation, composition and rhetoric. To this day, I can discern
more lasting influences proceeding
from that editorial den of mine
at Amherst, than from any other
one college source."

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 27, 1911.
COLUMBIA PAYS EXPENSES
Current Income and Gifts are Sufficient
to Meet the Running Expenses
of the University.

According to the report of John
McLean Nash, treasurer of Columbia University, the fiscal period ending June 30 was the first in many
years in which Columbia's current
income and gifts were sufficient to
meet the running expenses of the
University. The cost of carrying
on the work of the University proper, that is, exclusive of Barnard and
Teachers' College and the College
of Pharmacy, was $1,990,020. The
three other branches together were
maintained at a total cost of more
than $I,000,000.
Gifts, including those constituting a permanent fund, as well as
those donated for immediate use,
amounted to $2,535,064. The report further shows that collections
on the John Stewart Kennedy bequest amounted to $1,975,000, and
that the trustees had set the sum
aside as a separate endowment fund
for general educational purposes.
Of the George Crocker bequest for
cancer research, $693,333 had been
received, and a special committee
of seven, including President Butler, was named to formulate plans
for the development of research
work along this line. M. Nash's
report also mentioned receipt of
$27,970 from the Carnegie Foundation for professors'. pensions and
for allowances to widows of professors.

Medical School Notes.

The most important event last
week at the Medical School was a
lecture before the Medical Society,
by Dr. Howell, on "Coagulation of
the Blood." The lecture showed a
great amount of work on that subject, and was of the utmost interest
to the medical students.

MR. BOBBITT OBJECTS
(Continuedfrom page I.)

had something to do with the Interstate Contest, and won the Maryland Contest; and two of our
members, Mr. Rogers and Mr.
Dickinson, took high rank in the
essay competition conducted by the
Lake Mohonk Conference. The
Work that we did last year seems
to me ample justification for the
c9ntinuance of the society as a distinct organization.
I am not opposed to the introduction of a literary society; if I
Were still at the University, I should
be one of the first to support it;
but I cannot complacently see the
Arbitration Society swallowed up
m an organization of much broader
scope. If the great modern movements for international justice no
longer interest the students at Hopif these movements seem to
offer too limited a field for study
and discussion, why not frankly
abandon the Arbitration Society,
give it a respectable burial, and
organize a literary society independently?
But I do not believe that the Arbitration Society ought to be aband. oned. Certainly, the problems of
international relations are interestMg, vital problems. Surely there
Is material enough. both in the
achrevements of arbitration and
in
Current international events to keep
a College society busy. The schools
and colleges of this country are' beComing more and more interested
in these questions, and Hopkins
c.annot afford to lag behind. The
little fire of enthusiasm that was
kindled last year ought to be nursed
and fanned, instead of being snuffed
out. If final action has not already
been taken, I should be glad, indeed, to see the Arbitration Society
c.ontinue as a separate organization, adding some literary features,
Perhaps, but retaining its distinctive character and original purpose.
L. B. Ilollnirr.

November 14, 1911.
1'0 the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

I should like to call attention to
a case in which one of the editorials in THE NEWS-LETTER appears to have been founded upon
i nsufficient knowledge of the subject discussed. In the editorial upon
t,he "literary" society in last week's
issue, there occurs the following
statement: "The change which has
been made by the members of the
Arbitration Society in deciding that
the aim of their organization in the
future shall be of a literary character, is of doubtful wisdom. * * *
What we regret is that the arbitration element of the society has been
lost."
In the account of the Arbitration
Society's plans as reported three
Pages further on in the very same
issue this statement occurs: "Tt is
Proposed that the society shall devote two or. more meetings every
Year to the discussion of problems

connected with arbitration and that
it shall continue to hold the Maryland Intercollegiate Contests in
Oratory under its auspices; but that
at other times its functions shall be
those of a literary and debating
society." Thus it will be seen that
the arbitration element in the society has not been lost.
The experience of the Arbitration
Society itself during the past year,
and the example of most of the
other peace societies in existence,
prove beyond contradiction that
when the sphere of interest of an
organization is limited to a single
subject like peace, there is neither
interest enough aroused nor action
enough possible to justify more
than a few meetings a year. The
problem confronting the officers of
the Arbitration Society was, therefore, this: If the Society was to
continue, simply as an arbitration
society, it could hold not more than
two or three meetings a year respectably. Was there any excuse
for making it a more permanent
organization? THE NF;WS-LETTER
appears to think not, and alleges
that there are already quite enough
student societies. Where are they?
What are their names? The Musical Clubs, to be sure, have taken a
new lease on life. The Chess Club
appears to be struggling on after
some fashion or other. The Haresfoot Club is dead.
But are these societies so very
numerous? Or does any one of
them compete in the field which
the Arbitration Society proposes to
enter? The officers of the Arbitration Society thought not. They
believed that there was still room
at Hopkins for an organization
which might bring all the undergraduates together on a common
field of social intercourse and intellectual enjoyment; which side by
side with the pleasures of the
gridiron might render possible the
pleasures of the forum; but out
of respect to the founder of thc
Society, the increase of peace sentiment, and the progress of the world,
they emphatically resolved that the
arbitration element in the Society
should be, not lost, but faithfully
preserved.

JOHN S. DICKINSON.

[The author of this wail neglects to
m5ption that the editorial in question
said that "Here at Hopkins we had the
honor of having the first arbitration
society at any university in the Southeast." College arbitration societies are
someday going to be important factors
in working for peace. The Intercollegiate Peace Association is trying to organize a society in every college in the
country. One was organized at Hopkins, and its first year was prosperous.
THE, NEWS-LETTER doesn't want to
keep the author of this letter, or anyone else, from having an opportunity
to learn how to speak in public. In
order to accomplish their commendable
purpose, however, it isn't necessary for
the advocates of this new organization
to destroy the Arbitration Society.—

Troubles for Chinese Students:

The home town of Mr. Simon
Woo, the Chinaman now studying
medicine at Hopkins, seems to be
in the midst of the scene of operations of the present rebellion in
China. Mr. Woo comes from
Chang- Chow Foo, a city of broad
streets and fine shops. There, too,
is a magnificent Buddhist temple,
built in the eighth century. Last
Monday's paper said that this city,
with its 900,000 inhabitants, was
taken by the rebels. Most everyone who could, fled from the city
before the rebels got in, although
after the place was taken, no violence, except thievery, occurred.
Mr. Woo is not committing himself on the subject of the present
revolution, because, it must be remembered, he is an "American Indemnity Fund" student, who was
sent to America under the Empire.
If the rebels gain complete control,
it is not known whether it will affect Mr. Woo or not. However,
.the leaders of the rebels are for the
most part progressive and foreign
educated Chinese, and it is expected
that not only will the present students remain in America, but that
increased numbers will come over
in the future.
About 700 students have come to
this country in the first three years.
It is intended to continue sending
men until the fund gives out, which
is calculated to last for thirty years
more. The young men are divided
equally between the Eastern and
Western parts of the United States.
On our side of the continent, a
great many go to Cornell. Only
two are at Hopkins, Mr. Woo and
Mr. Hsueh-Wu Sun, a special student, who will later take graduate
work in chemistry. Mr. Woo says
that more men do not come to the
Hopkins Medical School because
they are frightened by the high requirements. He, himself, although
possessing a college degree from a
mission school, was forced to spend
last year in the undergraduate department.

MR. BOBBITT OBJECTS
Founder of the Arbitration Society Protests Against the Proposed Change
Into a Literary Organization.

Further discussion of the project
to change the Arbitration Society
into a literary organization is contained in the two letters which follow. The first, from Mr. L. B.
Bobbitt (A. B., 'ii), the organizer
of the Arbitration Society, endorses
THE NEWS-LETTER'S editorial of
November 13. The second, from
Mr. J. S. Dickinson, the president
of the Literary Society, attempts to
criticize the attitude of THE NEWS-

LETTER.
November 20, 1911.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER :
Dear Sir—Your issue of November 13 informs me that the Johns
Hopkins Arbitration Society has
resolved to transform itself into
a literary and debating society, and
.that a committee has been appointed to draft a new constitution. As
the organizer and president of the
Arbitration Society last yea,r, I regret exceedingly that this action
has been taken. In spite of the
proposal to devote at least two
meetings a year to the discussion
of matters pertaining to arbitration,
this new plan means that the distinctive . character of the Arbitration Society will be lost and that
the specific purpose for which it
was organized will be frustrated.
I believed last year, and the sentiment of a number of the students
confirmed my belief, that there was
a real place in the University for
a student society that should devote itself primarily to the study
of the judicial settlement of international disputes, and secondarily,
to the study of the peace movement
and international politics in general.
So far as I know, the Arbitration
Society that some of us formed
was the first college society of its /
kind in the country. For several//
Years a number of college literary
societies had, perhaps once or twice
a year, presented a program dealing with peace and arbitration; but
our society was, I think, the first
college society to devote itself to
these subjects exclusively. The
Work that we did, though not very
elaborate, was of some real value.
We held bi-weekly meetings, at
Which a number of excellent papers
Were presented by the members;
we were addressed by two prominent men, connected with the peace
movement, Hon. James Brown
Scott and Mr. Edwin D. Mead;
We arranged the details of the
aryland Oratorical Contest of the
Intercollegiate. Peace Association,

BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 27, 1911.

LECTURES BY DR. E. B. HUEY

DR. FINNEY DECLINES CALL

Course Dealing With Defective Children
Will Begin Early in January,
on Saturday Mornings.

Hopkins Professor Issues Statement Declining to be Considered for
President of Princeton.

Beginning early in January, at a
date to be announced shortly in the
public press, Dr. Edmund B. Huey,
who has recently been appointed
Lecturer on Mental Development
in the University and Assistant in
the Phipps Clinic of the Hospital,
will give a series of public lectures
on each Saturday that the University is in session, continuing to the
close of the university year.
The object of the course is, first,
to present some representative work
that is being done in the study and
treatment of defective children; second, to make as intelligible as possible, certain psychological conceptions which are currently used in
the study of cases.
After a very brief sketch of the
varied work with cases in many
parts of the world, and of the revision of psychology that is inevitably to come from this work, there
will be a presentation of the recently-adopted schema of • classification
and terminology for the various
grades of defectives. The operation of this schema will then be
illustrated by actual results obtained in handling cases at a large
State institution. The methods of
examining cases and of securing
the data needed for a proper casehistory will be illustrated. It is expected that there will be at least
two clinics in which mental examinations of children will be made
with the Binet scale. Various types
of mentally backward children as
found in school will be presented.
There will, of course, be opportunity for questions, and for such discussion as time may permit.
Besides these more practical presentations, the course will include
lectures on the intelligence, the
emotions and feelings in their relation to mental adaptation, the
tendencies to automatism, fixation
and limitation of mental response,
and the characteristics of infantilism and of various abnormal returns to "childish things" by individuals and by society. Certain
changes in these topics may be expedient as the course proceeds.
There can be relatively more of a
discussion of psychological theory
if the audience should prefer.
The lectures will begin at
o'cl6ck and will last one hour.
They will be open to the public as
well as to the members of the University. It is hoped' that they may
render a service to many who have
to do with defectives, as well as to
many ethers who have.an interest
in psychology.

Dr. John M. T. Finney, associate
professor of surgery in the Johns
Hopkins University issued a statement Friday afternoon in which he
said that he thought that Baltimore
offered more opportunities for the
work which he is fitted to do, than
would the presidency of Princeton
University. Hs formal statement
follows:
"Owing to the wide publicity
which, unfortunately, has been given
to the connection of my name with
the presidency of Princeton University, it is, perhaps, proper that
I should state the facts in the case
,in order that they may not be misunderstood. Sometime ago I was
approached by members of the
nominating committee of the Board
of Trustees of Princeton and asked
whether or not I would be willing
to have them present my name to
the Board for election to the presidency of the University.
"After most careful consideration,
from every point of view, I felt that
my work in Baltimore was not yet
done and, therefore, requested that
my name should be withdrawn.
While the call from Princeton,
which I consider one of the highest
honors that can fall to any man's
lot, came with peculiar force, it
seemed best that I should remain in
Baltimore. I felt that I was better
fitted for the work which T am now
doing."
Sophomore-Freshman Game.
The annual game of football between the sophomores and the freshmen will be played this coming Saturday, 3 P. M., at Homewood. The
sophomore class is one of three
classes which has won the game in
its first year at the University. It
defeated the Class of 1913 last fall,
18 to o, but it has lost "by graduation" five of its first string men,
the Riley brothers, Hill, Schreiber,
and Bryan. The loss depletes the
strength of the team nearly onehalf, but new men have been
brought out who will fill the vacancies and try to win again.
A second victory will give 194
a unique place in class history at
Hopkins, because no other class
team has won both games.
Both teams will practice regularly
this week.

CARLISLE WINS
The Conquerors of Harvard and Pcnn
Defeat Hopkins in a Spectacular Game

Hopkins lost last Saturday by the
score of 29 to 6, to the strongest
football team that has represented
Carlisle in recent years. The Indians
came to Baltimore with the record
of more points scored than any
other of the big teams of the East.
They have lost but one game this
year, and that to Syracuse, on a
muddy field; Saturday, however, the
sloppy condition of the field did not
seem to interfere with the Indians'
game, for they relied mostly on
quick end 'plays. Sousa, who played
such a fine game against Syracuse,
was a particularly bright star in
getting around the ends.
The first ten minutes of the game
consisted mainly in the exchange
of punts. The Hopkins line was
holding particularly well, and after
a few ineffectual attempts to gain,
the Indians would kick. The exchanges made but little difference
in the relative positions of the team,
so the Indians began to change
their tactics. It has been noticeable
the whole year, how slow the 'Varsity is in getting into place. The
Indians now took advantage of this
weakness, and by a quick dash
around Hopkins' left end, placed
the ball near the side lines on the
Hopkins half of the field. Before
Hopkins was settled again, the
Indians apparently attempted a mass
play through their left tackle. Meanwhile the man with the ball rushed
unhindered along the side line.
Score, 5 to o.
Shortly after the beginning of
the second -quarter, Gillet made a
kick from Hopkins' 25-yard line.
It was short, and Branham seized
the ball and got clear, but was
caught in mid-field by a swift
Indian runner. Carlisle soon got possession of the ball and by two long
end runs, supported by magnificent
441terference, and two line plunges,
put the ball over. Score, ii to 0.
The third touchdown was made
when Gillet was blocked in an attempt to kick from Hopkins' 25yard line and an Indian recovered
the ball. Score, 17 to o.
The Indians, receiving possession
of the ball, tried a forward pass,
which Pieper blocked. After getting the pigskin again on a punt,
the Indians made a 30-yard run
to Hopkins' 25-yard line. Here,
Quarterback Welch received a pass
and stood still for a moment as
if bewildered, then slowly drew the
ball back as if to make a forward

The St. John's Aftermath.

The aftermath of the football
games with Virginia and St. John's
has involved more controversy, in
newspapers and otherwise, than we
like to see. One fundamental principle of true sport is to accept the
outcome without protest. Such has
usually been the practice of our
neighbors from Annapolis, and we
honor them for it. On this occasion, too, the St. John's authorities
and students have shown themselves
willing to submit to a defeat at the
hands of a better team with good
feeling, just exactly as Hopkins has
done time after time when conditions were reversed; but a number
of over-zealous alumni and partisans of our rival institution have
filled the newspapers with howls
about the condition of the Homewood field, the personnel of the
Hopkins team, and various other
unworthily imagined grievances. To
these persons, we do not consider
it our place ,to reply. The facts
and conditions in question, which
have been brought out in several
able letters from prominent Hopkins graduates, are an adequate reflection of their somewhat ill-mannered attacks.
One public assault, however, was
too flagrant, and delivered in too
unfair a manner to be passed over.
THE NEWS-LETTER must object to
the treatment accorded the Hopkins
football team, and athletic authorities, in the account of the HopkinsSt. John's game which appeared in
The Sun. We leave the article itself to serve as a bill of particulars
to substantiate our complaint, and
are willing to accept the unprejudiced judgment of the spectators of
the game as to the unfairness and
inaccuracy of the statement it contains.
We cannot omit reference, also,
to the weights of the Hopkins plays, that have been published in the
local papers. We regret, exceed-

ingly, and we believe the students
unanimously join in regretting, that
the figures given out before the

The News-Letter Board.

THE NOVS-LETTER Board, owing to resignations, is now smaller
than it has been for sometime past,
and additions are contemplated. It
is certain that no freshmen, and
doubtful whether any upper classmen, will be elected until after the
Christmas holidays, and so there
is plenty of time for new candidates to announce themselves. Those
desiring to become editors should
speak to the Editor-in-Chief, while
the candidates for the business
department should speak to the
Business Manager.
Membership on THE NMS-LETTER Board is the greatest non-athletic honor which can be gained at
Hopkins, and some even subordinate athletics. A stated amount of
preliminary literary and business
work must be done by candidates
who want to be successful. Much
of this is assigned, but original
work is always welcomed. This
call for candidates is not made because there is a dearth of aspirants,
but because THE NEws-LETTER
wishes to have the best possible
Board.
Many who could easily "make
THE + F,WS-LETTER," refuse to be
candidates because they do not
think that they can spare the time
required. These students are generally the more serious minded,
who want to get all the good they
can while at Hopkins. The following excerpt from a letter written by the late Herbert B. Adams,
Professor of History, 1878-01, may
be of interest to them:
"My editorial connection with the
Amherst Student really gave a permanent bent to my life. I learned
more real useful knowledge in that
voluntary connection than in all
other college weave of training in
punctuation, composition and rhetoric. To this day, I can discern
more lasting influences proceeding
from that editorial den of mine
at Amherst, than from any other
one college source."

THE NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 27, 1911.
COLUMBIA PAYS EXPENSES
Current Income and Gifts are Sufficient
to Meet the Running Expenses
of the University.

According to the report of John
McLean Nash, treasurer of Columbia University, the fiscal period ending June 30 was the first in many
years in which Columbia's current
income and gifts were sufficient to
meet the running expenses of the
University. The cost of carrying
on the work of the University proper, that is, exclusive of Barnard and
Teachers' College and the College
of Pharmacy, was $1,990,020. The
three other branches together were
maintained at a total cost of more
than $I,000,000.
Gifts, including those constituting a permanent fund, as well as
those donated for immediate use,
amounted to $2,535,064. The report further shows that collections
on the John Stewart Kennedy bequest amounted to $1,975,000, and
that the trustees had set the sum
aside as a separate endowment fund
for general educational purposes.
Of the George Crocker bequest for
cancer research, $693,333 had been
received, and a special committee
of seven, including President Butler, was named to formulate plans
for the development of research
work along this line. M. Nash's
report also mentioned receipt of
$27,970 from the Carnegie Foundation for professors'. pensions and
for allowances to widows of professors.

November 14, 1911.
1'0 the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

I should like to call attention to
a case in which one of the editorials in THE NEWS-LETTER appears to have been founded upon
i nsufficient knowledge of the subject discussed. In the editorial upon
t,he "literary" society in last week's
issue, there occurs the following
statement: "The change which has
been made by the members of the
Arbitration Society in deciding that
the aim of their organization in the
future shall be of a literary character, is of doubtful wisdom. * * *
What we regret is that the arbitration element of the society has been
lost."
In the account of the Arbitration
Society's plans as reported three
Pages further on in the very same
issue this statement occurs: "Tt is
Proposed that the society shall devote two or. more meetings every
Year to the discussion of problems

connected with arbitration and that
it shall continue to hold the Maryland Intercollegiate Contests in
Oratory under its auspices; but that
at other times its functions shall be
those of a literary and debating
society." Thus it will be seen that
the arbitration element in the society has not been lost.
The experience of the Arbitration
Society itself during the past year,
and the example of most of the
other peace societies in existence,
prove beyond contradiction that
when the sphere of interest of an
organization is limited to a single
subject like peace, there is neither
interest enough aroused nor action
enough possible to justify more
than a few meetings a year. The
problem confronting the officers of
the Arbitration Society was, therefore, this: If the Society was to
continue, simply as an arbitration
society, it could hold not more than
two or three meetings a year respectably. Was there any excuse
for making it a more permanent
organization? THE NF;WS-LETTER
appears to think not, and alleges
that there are already quite enough
student societies. Where are they?
What are their names? The Musical Clubs, to be sure, have taken a
new lease on life. The Chess Club
appears to be struggling on after
some fashion or other. The Haresfoot Club is dead.
But are these societies so very
numerous? Or does any one of
them compete in the field which
the Arbitration Society proposes to
enter? The officers of the Arbitration Society thought not. They
believed that there was still room
at Hopkins for an organization
which might bring all the undergraduates together on a common
field of social intercourse and intellectual enjoyment; which side by
side with the pleasures of the
gridiron might render possible the
pleasures of the forum; but out
of respect to the founder of thc
Society, the increase of peace sentiment, and the progress of the world,
they emphatically resolved that the
arbitration element in the Society
should be, not lost, but faithfully
preserved.

JOHN S. DICKINSON.

[The author of this wail neglects to
m5ption that the editorial in question
said that "Here at Hopkins we had the
honor of having the first arbitration
society at any university in the Southeast." College arbitration societies are
someday going to be important factors
in working for peace. The Intercollegiate Peace Association is trying to organize a society in every college in the
country. One was organized at Hopkins, and its first year was prosperous.
THE, NEWS-LETTER doesn't want to
keep the author of this letter, or anyone else, from having an opportunity
to learn how to speak in public. In
order to accomplish their commendable
purpose, however, it isn't necessary for
the advocates of this new organization
to destroy the Arbitration Society.—

FOOTBALL TEAM

Troubles for Chinese Students:

The home town of Mr. Simon
Woo, the Chinaman now studying
medicine at Hopkins, seems to be
in the midst of the scene of operations of the present rebellion in
China. Mr. Woo comes from
Chang- Chow Foo, a city of broad
streets and fine shops. There, too,
is a magnificent Buddhist temple,
built in the eighth century. Last
Monday's paper said that this city,
with its 900,000 inhabitants, was
taken by the rebels. Most everyone who could, fled from the city
before the rebels got in, although
after the place was taken, no violence, except thievery, occurred.
Mr. Woo is not committing himself on the subject of the present
revolution, because, it must be remembered, he is an "American Indemnity Fund" student, who was
sent to America under the Empire.
If the rebels gain complete control,
it is not known whether it will affect Mr. Woo or not. However,
.the leaders of the rebels are for the
most part progressive and foreign
educated Chinese, and it is expected
that not only will the present students remain in America, but that
increased numbers will come over
in the future.
About 700 students have come to
this country in the first three years.
It is intended to continue sending
men until the fund gives out, which
is calculated to last for thirty years
more. The young men are divided
equally between the Eastern and
Western parts of the United States.
On our side of the continent, a
great many go to Cornell. Only
two are at Hopkins, Mr. Woo and
Mr. Hsueh-Wu Sun, a special student, who will later take graduate
work in chemistry. Mr. Woo says
that more men do not come to the
Hopkins Medical School because
they are frightened by the high requirements. He, himself, although
possessing a college degree from a
mission school, was forced to spend
last year in the undergraduate department.
